intro: Galium bloomeri var. hirsutum, commonly known as the hairy woodypoppy, is a perennial herb native to the southeastern United States. It is characterized by its hairy stems and small, white to pale pink flowers that bloom in late spring to early summer. The plant typically grows in moist, shaded woodlands and has opposite, ovate leaves with serrated edges. Its floral structure consists of five petals and five sepals, typical of the Rubiaceae family. The hairy texture of its stems and leaves is a distinguishing feature that aids in its identification.
